Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the fourth Midwest Women in Mathematics Symposium (WIMS), held April 2, 2016 at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. The symposium aims to: (1) recognize and advocate collective achievements by female mathematicians in the Midwest, and (2) stimulate collaborations, networking, and mentoring relations. The meeting builds upon the success of previous symposia to establish the WIMS as an annual event rotating among colleges and universities in the Midwest. The symposium will attract female mathematicians in the Midwest at all stages of their careers; it is expected to draw about 100 participants, in particular, graduate students, early-career researchers, and faculty at small institutions who have limited access to resources enabling them to attend conferences.

The symposium will feature two plenary lectures by distinguished senior researchers and eight shorter ones by promising junior researchers. The speakers are chosen to reflect the variety of institutions in the Midwest. Collectively, they will discuss a broad spectrum of cutting edge research. Lectures will be accompanied by open problem sessions, where the participants will work in small groups to discuss field-specific problems and develop new collaborations. Students and recent PhDs will contribute to the intellectual activity of the symposium by making poster presentations. This workshop is jointly funded by eight programs within the NSF Division of Mathematical Sciences: Algebra & Number Theory, Analysis, Applied Math, Infrastructure, Mathematical Biology, Topology & Geometric Analysis, Foundations, and Probability. More information about the conference can be found at http://www.math.illinois.edu/wims/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Award supported the fourth annual Midwest Women in Mathematics Symposium (WIMS), held April 2, 2016 at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. More than 130 women --- mostly graduate students, early career researchers, and faculty at small institutions --- from Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Ohio, Minnesota, and Wisconsin registered; about 90 people registered for the third WIMS. More than 100 registered participants were not local. The symposium consisted of two plenary lectures and eight short lectures, thirteen poster presentations, and open problem sessions --- from algebra and number theory, combinatorics and logic, geometry and topology, analysis and probability, partial differential equations, applied mathematics, and mathematical biology and to mathematics education. The plenary lectures were given by Gloria Mari Beffa (University of Wisconsin-Madison) and Barbara Keyfitz (Ohio State University). 

Lunchtime roundtable discussions explored issues facing women in mathematics including work-life balance: family, two-body issue/partner expectations, professional develoopment: finding mentors, balancing teaching and research, unspoken expectations, career track options: teaching versus research versus a mix, and how to figure out what you want, and ways to get involved in research collaborations. Wendy Heller, Illinois Professor of Psychology and Gender and Women's Studies, delivered opening remarks. These helped women in mathematics at early stages of their careers through the crucial passages from the graduate school to postdoc, to faculty position to tenure.  The symposium provided a sense of community among women in mathematics in the Midwest, established research collaborations and mentoring relations. 

The full schedule of the symposium, including slides and videos of the plenary lectures, is online at www.math.illinois.edu/wims/.

The PI recruited other midwest institutions to host future WIMS. The next ones will be held at Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis (2017) and Purdue University (2018). The IUPUI organizers successfully obtained an NSF award.
